Abstract

Standard game theory assumes that the structure of the game is common knowledge among players. We relax this assumption by considering extensive games where agents may be unaware of the complete structure of the game. In particular, they may not be aware of moves that they and other agents can make. We show how such games can be represented; the key idea is to describe the game from the point of view of every agent at every node of the game tree. We provide a generalization of Nash equilibrium and show that every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium. Finally, we extend these results to games with awareness of unawareness, where a player iğ‘–i may be aware that a player jğ‘—j can make moves that iğ‘–i is not aware of, and to subjective games, where payers may have no common knowledge regarding the actual game and their beliefs are incompatible with a common prior.

keywords: Economic Theory, Foundations of Game Theory, Awareness, Solution Concepts.

1 Introduction

Standard game theory models implicitly assume that all significant aspects of the game (payoffs, moves available, etc.) are common knowledge among the players. While such common knowledge may seem unreasonable, there are well-known techniques going back to Harsanyi [?] for transforming a game where some aspects are not common knowledge to one where they are common knowledge. All these techniques assume that players are at least aware of all possible moves in the game. However, this is not always a reasonable assumption. For example, sleazy companies assume that consumers are not aware that they can lodge complaints if there are problems; in a war setting, having technology that an enemy is unaware of (and thus being able to make moves that the enemy is unaware of) can be critical; in financial markets, some investors may not be aware of certain investment strategies (complicated hedging strategies, for example, or tax-avoidance strategies).

In a standard game, a set of strategies is a Nash equilibrium if each agentâ€™s strategy is a best response to the other agentsâ€™ strategies, so each agent iğ‘–i would continue playing its strategy even if iğ‘–i knew what strategies the other agents were using. To understand the relevance of adding the possibility of unawareness to the analysis of games, consider the game shown in FigureÂ 1. One Nash equilibrium of this game has Ağ´A playing acrossA and BğµB playing downB. However, suppose that Ağ´A is not aware that BğµB can play downB. In that case, if Ağ´A is rational, Ağ´A will play downA. Therefore, Nash equilibrium does not seem to be the appropriate solution concept here. Although Ağ´A would play acrossA if Ağ´A knew that BğµB were going to play downB, Ağ´A cannot even contemplate this possibility, let alone know it.

Our goal is to find appropriate solution concepts for extensive games with possibly unaware players, and more generally, to find ways of representing multiagent systems where some agents may not be aware of features of the system. To do this, we must first find an appropriate representation for such games. The first step in doing so is to explicitly represent what players are aware of at each node. We do this by using what we call an augmented game. An augmented game describes how awareness changes over time. For example, perhaps Ağ´A playing acrossA will result in BğµB becoming aware of the possibility of playing downB. In financial settings, one effect of players using certain investment strategies is that other players become aware of the possibility of using that strategy. Strategic thinking in such games must involve taking this possibility into account.

We cannot in general represent what is going on using only one augmented game. The standard representation of a game implicitly assumes that (it is common knowledge that) the modeler and the players all understand the game the same way. This is no longer true once we allow for the possibility of unawareness, since a playerâ€™s description of the game can now involve only those aspects of the game that he is aware of. Thus, the full description of the game with awareness is given by a set of augmented games, one for the modeler and one for each game that at least one of the agents thinks might be the true game in some situation.

Continuing with the game in FigureÂ 1, the augmented game from the point of view of the type of BğµB that is unaware of the possibility of playing downB would just include Ağ´Aâ€™s moves downA and acrossA and the move acrossB. In that augmented game, player Ağ´A is also unaware of the move downB. By way of contrast, the augmented game from the point of view of the type of BğµB that is aware of downB would include the move downB, but may also allow for the possibility that Ağ´A is not aware that BğµB is aware of this move.

The standard notion of Nash equilibrium consists of a collection of strategies, one for each player. Our generalization consists of a collection of strategies, one for each pair (i,Î“â€²)ğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²(i,\Gamma^{\prime}), where Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} is a game that agent iğ‘–i considers to be the true game in some situation. Intuitively, the strategy for a player iğ‘–i at Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} is the strategy iğ‘–i would play in situations where iğ‘–i believes that the true game is Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}. To understand why we may need to consider different strategies consider, for example, the game of FigureÂ 1. BğµB would play differently depending on whether or not he was aware of downB. Roughly speaking, a set of strategies, one for each pair (i,Î“â€²)ğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²(i,\Gamma^{\prime}), is a generalized Nash equilibrium if the strategy for (i,Î“â€²)ğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²(i,\Gamma^{\prime}) is a best response for player iğ‘–i if the true game is Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}, given the strategies being used by the other players in Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}.

We argue that this notion of equilibrium correctly captures our intuitions. We then show that every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium by associating with a game with awareness a standard game (where agents are aware of all moves) such that there is a one-to-one correspondence between generalized Nash equilibria of the game with awareness and Nash equilibria of the standard game.

For ease of exposition, for most of the paper we focus on games where agents are not aware of their lack of awareness. That is, we do not consider games where one player might be aware that there are moves that another player (or even she herself) might be able to make, although she is not aware of what they are. Such awareness of unawareness can be quite relevant in practice. For example, in the war setting described above, even if one side cannot conceive of a new technology available to the enemy, they might believe that there is some move available to the enemy without understanding what that particular move is. This, in turn, may encourage peace overtures. To take another example, an agent might delay making a decision because she considers it possible that she might learn about more possible moves, even if she is not aware of what these moves are.

If we interpret â€œlack of awarenessâ€ as â€œunable to computeâ€ (cf.Â [2]), then awareness of unawareness becomes even more significant. Consider a chess game. Although all players understand in principle all the moves that can be made, they are certainly not aware of all consequences of all moves. A more accurate representation of chess would model this computational unawareness explicitly. We provide such a representation.

Roughly speaking, we capture the fact that player iğ‘–i is aware that, at a node hâ„h in the game tree, there is a move that jğ‘—j can make she (iğ‘–i) is not aware by having iğ‘–iâ€™s subjective representation of the game include a â€œvirtualâ€ move for jğ‘—j at node hâ„h. Since iğ‘–i might have only an incomplete understanding of what can happen after this move,

iğ‘–i simply describes what she believes will be the game after the virtual move, to the extent that she can. For example, if she has no idea what will happen after the virtual move, then she can describe her beliefs regarding the payoffs of the game. Thus, our representation can be viewed as a generalization of how chess programs analyze chess games. They explore the game tree up to a certain point, and then evaluate the board position at that point. We can think of the payoffs following a virtual move by jğ‘—j in iğ‘–iâ€™s subjective representation of a chess game as describing the evaluation of the board from iğ‘–iâ€™s point of view. This seems like a much more reasonable representation of the game than the standard complete game tree!

Our framework is flexible enough to deal with games where there is lack of common knowledge about what is the game being played. In particular, we can deal with lack of common knowledge regarding the utilities, who moves next, the structure of other playersâ€™ information sets, and the probability of natureâ€™s moves (even in cases where there is no common prior compatible with the playersâ€™ beliefs regarding nature).

Recently, FeinbergÂ [?, ?] also studied games with awareness. FeinbergÂ [?] gives a definition of extended Nash equilibrium in normal-form games. Although his definition stems from much the same intuitions as ours (although some details are differentâ€”see SectionÂ 6), it is expressed syntactically. Each player is characterized by a complete description of what moves and players he is aware of, what moves and players he is aware that each other player is aware of, and so on through all levels of iterated awareness. FeinbergÂ [?] deals with extensive-form games and defines solution concepts only indirectly, via a syntactic epistemic characterization. His approach lacks a more direct semantic framework, which our model provides. He also does not deal with awareness of unawareness.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we describe how we represent different awareness levels in a game. In SectionÂ 3, we use our representation to define a generalized notion of Nash equilibrium, and we prove its existence in games with awareness. In SectionÂ 4, we describe how we can extend our approach to deal with awareness of unawareness. In SectionÂ 5, we describe how to extend our framework to deal with games where there is lack of common knowledge, even if awareness is not an issue. We compare our work to others in the literature, particularly Feinbergâ€™s, in SectionÂ 6, and conclude in SectionÂ 7.

2 Modeling awareness

The first step in dealing with awareness is modeling it. To this end, we consider augmented games. We start with a standard game, described by a game tree Î“Î“\Gamma (as in FigureÂ 1). An augmented game Î“+superscriptÎ“\Gamma^{+} based on Î“Î“\Gamma essentially augments Î“Î“\Gamma by describing each agentâ€™s awareness level at each node, where player iğ‘–iâ€™s awareness level at a node hâ„h is essentially the set of runs (complete histories) in Î“Î“\Gamma that iğ‘–i is aware of at node hâ„h. A playerâ€™s awareness level may change over time, as the player becomes aware of more moves.

Our formal definition of augmented game is based on the definition of extensive game given by Osborne and Rubinstein [?]. We start by briefly reviewing Osborne and Rubinsteinâ€™s definition.

Conditions A1â€“A12 are intended to capture our intuitions regarding information sets, awareness, and common knowledge. To allow us to focus on issues directly related to awareness, we have implicitly assumed that there is common knowledge of (1) who moves at histories in the underlying game (this is captured by the fact that P+â€‹(h)=Pâ€‹(hÂ¯)superscriptğ‘ƒâ„ğ‘ƒÂ¯â„P^{+}(h)=P(\overline{h}) unless P+â€‹(h)=csuperscriptğ‘ƒâ„ğ‘P^{+}(h)=c and Mh+âˆ©M=âˆ…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â„ğ‘€M^{+}_{h}\cap M=\emptyset â€”either the same player or nature moves at both hâ„h and hÂ¯Â¯â„\overline{h} unless nature makes an â€œawarenessâ€ move at hâ„h), (2) what the payoffs are in the underlying game (since u+â€‹(zÂ¯)=uâ€‹(z)superscriptğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘§ğ‘¢ğ‘§u^{+}(\overline{z})=u(z)), and (3) what the information sets are in the underlying game (see A8â€“A10). Our approach is flexible enough to allow us to drop these assumptions; see SectionÂ 5.

To understand A8â€“A10, we must first discuss our view of information sets. As pointed out by HalpernÂ [?], special attention must be given to the interpretation of information sets in game trees. This issue requires even more care in games with awareness. The standard intuition for information sets is that a player considers all the histories in his information set possible. But this intuition does not apply in augmented games. In an augmented game, there may be some histories in an iğ‘–i-information set that iğ‘–i is not aware of; player iğ‘–i cannot consider these histories possible. For example, consider finitely repeated prisoners dilemma where Alice and Bob each move twice before their moves are revealed. Even if Bob is not aware of defection, his information set after Aliceâ€™s first move in the modelerâ€™s game will still contain the history where Alice defects.

We interpret an iğ‘–i-information set to be the set of all histories where player iğ‘–i has the same local state. Intuitively, this local states encodes all the information that iğ‘–i has about the moves he can make, what moves have been made, the other players in the game, his strategy, and so on. We assume that player iğ‘–iâ€™s local state is characterized by the sequence of signals that that iğ‘–i has received in the course of the game. Therefore, hâ„h and hâ€²superscriptâ„â€²h^{\prime} are in the same iğ‘–i-information set in Î“Î“\Gamma iff iğ‘–i received the same sequence of signals in both histories.

In standard extensive games, the sequence of signals a player receives after every history hâ„h is assumed to be common knowledge. (This assumption is implicit in the assumption that the game, is common knowledge, and hence so are the information sets.) As we said, we continue to assume this in games with awareness (although we show how the assumption can be dropped in SectionÂ 5). That is why we require in A8 that if hâ„h and hâ€²superscriptâ„â€²h^{\prime} are in the same iğ‘–i-information in an augmented game, then hÂ¯Â¯â„\overline{h} and hÂ¯â€²superscriptÂ¯â„â€²\overline{h}^{\prime} must be in the same iğ‘–i-information set in the underlying game. The converse of A8 does not necessarily hold. It could well be the case that hÂ¯Â¯â„\overline{h} and hÂ¯â€²superscriptÂ¯â„â€²\overline{h}^{\prime} are in the same iğ‘–i-information set, but since iğ‘–i receives different signals from nature, hâ„h and hâ€²superscriptâ„â€²h^{\prime} are not in the same information set. On the other hand, if all the moves in hâ„h and hâ€²superscriptâ„â€²h^{\prime} are already in the underlying game, then if hâ„h and hâ€²superscriptâ„â€²h^{\prime} are in the same information set of Î“Î“\Gamma, they should be in the same information set of Î“+superscriptÎ“\Gamma^{+}. This is the content of A9. Since, the signals received by a player determine the moves he has available, if player iğ‘–i is aware of two histories in the same information set in Î“Î“\Gamma, he must be aware of the same set of moves available at both of these histories. A10 captures that intuition.

For the remainder of the paper, we use the following notation: for a (standard or augmented) game Î“ssuperscriptÎ“ğ‘ \Gamma^{s}, we denote the components of Î“ssuperscriptÎ“ğ‘ \Gamma^{s} with the same superscript sğ‘ s, so that we have Mssuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘ M^{s}, Hssuperscriptğ»ğ‘ H^{s}, and so on. Thus, from here on we do not explicitly describe the components of a game.

An augmented game describes either the modelerâ€™s view of the game or the subjective view of the game of one of the players, and includes both moves of the underlying game and moves of nature that change awareness. For example, consider again the game shown in FigureÂ 1 and suppose that

As this example should make clear, to model a game with possibly unaware players, we need to consider not just one augmented game, but a collection of them. Moreover, we need to describe, at each history in an augmented game, which augmented game the player playing at that history believes is the actual augmented game being played.

M1, M2 and M3 enforce the intuition that the modeler understands the underlying game. It may seem somewhat surprising that there is no analogue of the second part of M3 (i.e., the constraint of fcmsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘šf_{c}^{m}) for all augmented games. It does not seem reasonable to assume that this awareness should come along with an understanding of the probabilities of these moves. Of course, we could require such an analogue of M3. Since the set of games that have such a requirement is a subset of the games we consider, all our results apply without change if such a requirement is imposed.

The intuition behind condition C9 is that player iğ‘–i knows that player jğ‘—j only make moves that jğ‘—j is aware of. Since we assume that players have (modulo awareness) common knowledge about information sets, if Î“+superscriptÎ“\Gamma^{+} is the game from the point of view of player jğ‘—j (or the modeler) and there are histories hâ€²superscriptâ„â€²h^{\prime} and hâ€²â€²superscriptâ„â€²â€²h^{\prime\prime} in both Î“+superscriptÎ“\Gamma^{+} and Î“hsuperscriptÎ“â„\Gamma^{h}, then player jğ‘—j (or the modeler) knows that player iğ‘–i gets the same signals in both hâ€²superscriptâ„â€²h^{\prime} and hâ€²â€²superscriptâ„â€²â€²h^{\prime\prime} iff he knows that player iğ‘–i knows that he gets the same signals in those histories. C10 captures that intuition.

Just as Î“msuperscriptÎ“ğ‘š\Gamma^{m} is not uniquely determined by Î“Î“\Gamma, â„±â€‹(Î“+,h)â„±superscriptÎ“â„{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h) depends on more than just the awareness level of the player who moves at hâ„h. That is, even if Aiâ€‹(h)=Aiâ€‹(hâ€²)subscriptğ´ğ‘–â„subscriptğ´ğ‘–superscriptâ„â€²{A}_{i}(h)={A}_{i}(h^{\prime}), we may have â„±â€‹(Î“+,h)=(Î“h,I)â„±superscriptÎ“â„superscriptÎ“â„ğ¼{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{h},I) and â„±â€‹(Î“+,hâ€²)=(Î“hâ€²,Iâ€²)â„±superscriptÎ“superscriptâ„â€²superscriptÎ“superscriptâ„â€²superscriptğ¼â€²{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h^{\prime})=(\Gamma^{h^{\prime}},I^{\prime}) with Î“hâ‰ Î“hâ€²superscriptÎ“â„superscriptÎ“superscriptâ„â€²\Gamma^{h}\neq\Gamma^{h^{\prime}}. We do not require that the awareness level determines the game a player considers possible. This extra flexibility allows us to model a situation where, for example, players 2 and 3, who have the same awareness level and agree on the awareness level of player 1, have different beliefs about the game player 1 considers possible.222If the beliefs of players 2 and 3 regarding 1 are compatible with a common prior, then we can view players 2 and 3 as considering different information sets in the same game possible. A standard extensive game Î“Î“\Gamma can be identified with the game ({Î“m},Î“m,â„±)superscriptÎ“ğ‘šsuperscriptÎ“ğ‘šâ„±(\{\Gamma^{m}\},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}), where (abusing notation slightly) Î“m=(Î“,{Ai:iâˆˆN})superscriptÎ“ğ‘šÎ“conditional-setsubscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\Gamma^{m}=(\Gamma,\{{A}_{i}:i\in N\}) and, for all histories hâ„h in an iğ‘–i-information set Iğ¼I in Î“Î“\Gamma, Aiâ€‹(h)=Hsubscriptğ´ğ‘–â„ğ»{A}_{i}(h)=H and â„±â€‹(Î“m,h)=(Î“m,I)â„±superscriptÎ“ğ‘šâ„superscriptÎ“ğ‘šğ¼{\cal F}(\Gamma^{m},h)=(\Gamma^{m},I). Thus, all players are aware of all the runs in Î“Î“\Gamma, and agree with each other and the modeler that the game is Î“Î“\Gamma. We call this the canonical representation of Î“Î“\Gamma as a game with awareness.

One technical issue: We have assumed that the set ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} of games in a game Î“âˆ—superscriptÎ“\Gamma^{*} with awareness is countable. For our purposes, this is without loss of generality. We are ultimately interested in what happens in the game Î“msuperscriptÎ“ğ‘š\Gamma^{m}, since this is the game actually being played. However, to analyze that, we need to consider what happens in other games in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G}. It is not hard to see that the set of games we need to consider is the least set ğ’¢â€²superscriptğ’¢â€²{\cal G}^{\prime} such that Î“mâˆˆğ’¢â€²superscriptÎ“ğ‘šsuperscriptğ’¢â€²\Gamma^{m}\in{\cal G}^{\prime} and, for every Î“â€²âˆˆğ’¢superscriptÎ“â€²ğ’¢\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G} and history hâ„h in Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} such that â„±â€‹(Î“â€²,h)=(Î“â€²â€²,â‹…)â„±superscriptÎ“â€²â„superscriptÎ“â€²â€²â‹…{\cal F}(\Gamma^{\prime},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime\prime},\cdot), Î“â€²â€²âˆˆğ’¢â€²superscriptÎ“â€²â€²superscriptğ’¢â€²\Gamma^{\prime\prime}\in{\cal G}^{\prime}. ğ’¢â€²superscriptğ’¢â€²{\cal G}^{\prime} is guaranteed to be countable, even if ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} is not.

3 Local strategies and generalized Nash equilibrium

3.1 Local Strategies

In this section, we generalize the notion of Nash equilibrium to games with awareness. To do that, we must first define what a strategy is in a game with awareness. Recall that in a standard game, a strategy for player iğ‘–i is a function from iğ‘–i-information sets to a move or to a distribution over moves, depending on whether we are considering pure (i.e., deterministic) strategies or behavioral (i.e., randomized) strategies. The intuition is that player iğ‘–iâ€™s actions depend on what iğ‘–i knows; the strategy can be viewed as a universal plan, describing what iğ‘–i will do in every possible situation that can arise. This makes sense only because iğ‘–i is presumed to know the game tree, and thus to know in advance all the situations that can arise.

In games with awareness, this intuition no longer makes sense. For example, player iğ‘–i cannot plan in advance for what will happen if he becomes aware of something he is initially unaware of. We must allow iğ‘–iâ€™s strategy to change if he becomes aware of more moves. Let ğ’¢i={Î“â€²âˆˆğ’¢:for someÂ â€‹Î“+âˆˆğ’¢â€‹Â andÂ â€‹hâ€‹Â inÂ â€‹Î“+,P+â€‹(h)=iâ€‹Â andÂ â€‹â„±â€‹(Î“+,h)=(Î“â€²,â‹…)}subscriptğ’¢ğ‘–conditional-setsuperscriptÎ“â€²ğ’¢formulae-sequencefor someÂ superscriptÎ“ğ’¢Â andÂ â„Â inÂ superscriptÎ“superscriptğ‘ƒâ„ğ‘–Â andÂ â„±superscriptÎ“â„superscriptÎ“â€²â‹…{\cal G}_{i}=\{\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}:\,\mbox{for some }\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}\mbox{ and }h\mbox{ in }\Gamma^{+},\,P^{+}(h)=i\mbox{ and }{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime},\cdot)\}. Intuitively, ğ’¢isubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–{\cal G}_{i} consists of the games that iğ‘–i views as the real game in some history. Thus, rather than considering a single strategy in a game Î“âˆ—=(ğ’¢,Î“m,â„±)superscriptÎ“ğ’¢superscriptÎ“ğ‘šâ„±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) with awareness, we consider a collection {Ïƒi,Î“â€²:Î“â€²âˆˆğ’¢i}conditional-setsubscriptğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²subscriptğ’¢ğ‘–\{\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}:\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}\} of what we call local strategies, one for each augmented game in ğ’¢isubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–{\cal G}_{i}. Intuitively, a local strategy Ïƒi,Î“â€²subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} for game Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} is the strategy that iğ‘–i would use if iğ‘–i were called upon to play and iğ‘–i thought that the true game was Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}. The following definition summarizes this discussion.

Definition 3.1

Note that there may be no relationship between the strategies Ïƒi,Î“â€²subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} for different games Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}. Intuitively, this is because discovering about the possibility of a different move may cause agent iğ‘–i to totally alter his strategy. We could impose some consistency requirements, but we have not found any that we believe should hold in all games. We believe that all our results would continue to hold in the presence of reasonable additional requirements, although we have not explored the space of such requirements.

3.2 Generalized Nash Equilibrium

We want to define a notion of generalized Nash equilibrium so as to capture the intuition that for every player iğ‘–i, if iğ‘–i believes he is playing game Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}, then his local strategy Ïƒi,Î“â€²subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} is a best response to the local strategies of other players inÂ Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}.

Define a generalized strategy profile of Î“âˆ—=(ğ’¢,Î“m,â„±)superscriptÎ“ğ’¢superscriptÎ“ğ‘šâ„±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) to be a set of local strategies Ïƒâ†’={Ïƒi,Î“â€²:iâˆˆN,Î“â€²âˆˆğ’¢i}â†’ğœconditional-setsubscriptğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²formulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ‘superscriptÎ“â€²subscriptğ’¢ğ‘–\vec{\sigma}=\{\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}:i\in N,\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}\}. Let Eâ€‹Ui,Î“â€²â€‹(Ïƒâ†’)ğ¸subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²â†’ğœEU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\vec{\sigma}) be the expected payoff for iğ‘–i in the game Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} given that strategy profile Ïƒâ†’â†’ğœ\vec{\sigma} is used. Note that the only strategies in Ïƒâ†’â†’ğœ\vec{\sigma} that are needed to compute Eâ€‹Ui,Î“â€²â€‹(Ïƒâ†’)ğ¸subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²â†’ğœEU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\vec{\sigma}) are the strategies actually used in Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}; indeed, all that is needed is the restriction of these strategies to information sets that arise in Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}.

A generalized Nash equilibrium of Î“âˆ—=(ğ’¢,Î“m,â„±)superscriptÎ“ğ’¢superscriptÎ“ğ‘šâ„±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) is a generalized strategy profile Ïƒâ†’â†’ğœ\vec{\sigma} such that for all Î“â€²âˆˆğ’¢isuperscriptÎ“â€²subscriptğ’¢ğ‘–\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}, the local strategy Ïƒi,Î“â€²subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} is a best response to Ïƒâ†’âˆ’(i,Î“â€²)subscriptâ†’ğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²\vec{\sigma}_{-(i,\Gamma^{\prime})}, where Ïƒâ†’âˆ’(i,Î“â€²)subscriptâ†’ğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²\vec{\sigma}_{-(i,\Gamma^{\prime})} is the set of all local strategies in Ïƒâ†’â†’ğœ\vec{\sigma} except Ïƒi,Î“â€²subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}.

Definition 3.2

A generalized strategy profile Ïƒâ†’âˆ—superscriptâ†’ğœ\vec{\sigma}^{*} is a generalized Nash equilibrium of a game Î“âˆ—=(ğ’¢,Î“m,â„±)superscriptÎ“ğ’¢superscriptÎ“ğ‘šâ„±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) with awareness if, for every player iğ‘–i, game Î“â€²âˆˆğ’¢isuperscriptÎ“â€²subscriptğ’¢ğ‘–\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}, and local strategy Ïƒğœ\sigma for iğ‘–i in Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime},

Eâ€‹Ui,Î“â€²â€‹(Ïƒâ†’âˆ—)â‰¥Eâ€‹Ui,Î“â€²â€‹((Ïƒâ†’âˆ’(i,Î“â€²)âˆ—,Ïƒ)).ğ¸subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²superscriptâ†’ğœğ¸subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²subscriptsuperscriptâ†’ğœğ‘–superscriptÎ“â€²ğœEU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\vec{\sigma}^{*})\geq EU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}((\vec{\sigma}^{*}_{-(i,\Gamma^{\prime})},\sigma)).

The standard definition of Nash equilibrium would say that Ïƒâ†’â†’ğœ\vec{\sigma} is a Nash equilibrium if Ïƒisubscriptğœğ‘–\sigma_{i} is a best response to Ïƒâ†’âˆ’isubscriptâ†’ğœğ‘–\vec{\sigma}_{-i}. This definition implicitly assumes that player iğ‘–i can choose a whole strategy. This is inappropriate in our setting. An agent cannot anticipate that he will become aware of more moves. Essentially, if Î“1â‰ Î“2subscriptÎ“1subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{1}\neq\Gamma_{2}, we are treating player iğ‘–i who considers the true game to be Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} to be a different agent from the version of player iğ‘–i who considers Î“2subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{2} to be the true game. To understand why this is appropriate, suppose that player iğ‘–i considers Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} to be the true game, and then learns about more moves, and so considers Î“2subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{2} to be the true game. At that point, it is too late for player iğ‘–i to change the strategy he was playing when he thought the game was Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1}. He should just try to play optimally for what he now considers the true game. Moreover, while player iğ‘–i thinks that the game Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} is the true game, he never considers it possible that he will ever be playing a different game, so that he cannot â€œprepare himselfâ€ for a change in his subjective view of the game.333 In games with awareness of unawareness, an agent may consider it possible that he will become aware of more information. But this too is incorporated in his view of the game, so he can still do no better than playing optimally in his current view of the game. These considerations suggest that our notion of Nash equilibrium is appropriate.

It is easy to see that Ïƒâ†’â†’ğœ\vec{\sigma} is a Nash equilibrium of a standard game iff Ïƒâ†’â†’ğœ\vec{\sigma} is a (generalized) Nash equilibrium of the canonical representation of Î“Î“\Gamma as a game with awareness. Thus, our definition of generalized Nash equilibrium generalizes the standard definition.

Intuitively, Ağ´A believes BğµB will play acrossB no matter what he (BğµB) is aware of, and therefore plays downA; given that Ağ´A plays downA, BğµB cannot improve by playing downB even is he is aware of that move.444We did not discuss this latter equilibrium in the preliminary version of this paper.

We now show that every game with awareness has at least one generalized Nash equilibrium. We proceed as follows. Corollary 3.1

Every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium.

4 Modeling Awareness of Unawareness

In this section, we describe how to extend our representation of games with awareness to deal with awareness of unawareness. In an augmented game that represents player iğ‘–iâ€™s subjective view of the game, we want to model the fact that iğ‘–i may be aware of the fact that jğ‘—j can make moves at a history hâ„h that iğ‘–i is not aware of. We do this by allowing jğ‘—j to make a â€œvirtual moveâ€ at history hâ„h. Histories that contain virtual moves are called virtual histories. These virtual histories do not necessarily correspond to a history in the underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma (i.e., iğ‘–i may falsely believe that jğ‘—j can make a move at hâ„h that he is unaware of), and even if a virtual history does correspond to a history in Î“Î“\Gamma, the subgame that follows that virtual history may bear no relationship to the actual subgame that follows the corresponding history in the underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma. Intuitively, the virtual histories describe agent iğ‘–iâ€™s (possibly incomplete and possibly incorrect) view of what would happen in the game if some move she is unaware of is made by agent jğ‘—j. Player jğ‘—j may have several virtual moves available at history hâ„h, and may make virtual moves at a number of histories in the augmented game.555In the preliminary version of the paper, we assumed that all virtual moves were terminal moves. This is appropriate if iğ‘–i has no idea at all of what will happen in the game after a virtual move is made. The greater generality we allow here is useful to model situations where player iğ‘–i has some partial understanding of the game. For example, iğ‘–i may know that he can move left after jğ‘—jâ€™s virtual move, no matter what that virtual move is. Note that agent iğ‘–iâ€™s subjective game may include virtual moves for iğ‘–i himself; iğ‘–i may believe that he will become aware of more moves (and may take active steps to try and learn about these moves).

To handle awareness of unawareness, we consider a generalization of the notion of augmented game. We continue to refer to the generalized notion as an augmented game, using â€œaugmented game without awareness of unawarenessâ€ to refer to the special case we have focused on up to now. We can now define local strategies, generalized strategy profiles, and generalized Nash equilibrium just as we did for games with awareness. The same technique as that used to show CorollaryÂ 3.1 can be used to prove the following.

Theorem 4.1

Every game with awareness of unawareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium.

5 Modeling Lack of Common Knowledge

Game theorists have long searched for good approaches to modeling games where there is no common knowledge among players regarding the game being played. Our approach is flexible enough to handle such lack of common knowledge. In this section, we discuss the changes needed to handle lack of common knowledge. We remark that what we do here makes perfect sense even in games where there is full awareness.

We can modify our model to accommodate four different aspects of lack of common knowledge.

  • â€¢

    Lack of common knowledge regarding who moves. We assumed that every player understands who moves in each history he is aware of. Although we still need to require that every player knows when it is his turn to move, we can handle the case where a player has false beliefs about who moves after a history that is not in one of his information sets. For example, we are interested in modeling the case where player iğ‘–i may be confused after some history hâ„h as to whether player jğ‘—j or player kğ‘˜k moves, but in both cases iğ‘–i still believes that the same moves are available. That is, player iğ‘–i knows what could happen next, but he does not know who is going to do it. (Later we model uncertainty not only regarding who moves but also regarding what the move is.)

    To explain the necessary modifications, we need one more definition. Let ğ’¢m,isubscriptğ’¢ğ‘šğ‘–{\cal G}_{m,i} be the smallest subset of ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} such that if either Î“+=Î“msuperscriptÎ“superscriptÎ“ğ‘š\Gamma^{+}=\Gamma^{m} or Î“+âˆˆğ’¢m,isuperscriptÎ“subscriptğ’¢ğ‘šğ‘–\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}_{m,i}, hâˆˆH+â„superscriptğ»h\in H^{+}, P+â€‹(h)=isuperscriptğ‘ƒâ„ğ‘–P^{+}(h)=i, and â„±â€‹(Î“+,h)=(Î“â€²,â‹…)â„±superscriptÎ“â„superscriptÎ“â€²â‹…{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime},\cdot), then Î“â€²âˆˆğ’¢m,isuperscriptÎ“â€²subscriptğ’¢ğ‘šğ‘–\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{m,i}.     This approach of allowing the augmented games in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} to be based on different underlying games actually subsumes our earlier approach and allows us to capture lack of common knowledge about who moves, what the information sets are, and what the payoffs are. For example, note that despite the fact that we have replaced A3-5 by M1-3, we can also model games with awareness using this approach by taking the game Î“â€‹(h)Î“â„\Gamma(h) to be the game consisting only of the runs of Î“Î“\Gamma that are in A+â€‹(h)superscriptğ´â„{A}^{+}(h). (Of course, if we do that, we need to reinstate A7 and replace C2â€²â€² with C2.) To capture lack of common knowledge about who moves, we take Î“â€‹(h)Î“â„\Gamma(h) to be identical to Î“Î“\Gamma except that different agents may move at a given information set. Similarly, we can model lack of common knowledge about what the information sets and what the payoffs are by restricting Î“â€‹(h)Î“â„\Gamma(h) appropriately.

Despite all the changes to the conditions, the definitions of local strategies and generalized Nash equilibrium, and the theorems and their proofs remain unchanged. Thus, our techniques can deal with highly subjective games as well as awareness.

6 Related Work

There have been a number of models for unawareness in the literature (see, for example, [2, 14, 20, 21, 1]). Halpern [?] and Halpern and RÃªgo [?] showed that in a precise sense all those models are special cases of Fagin and Halpernâ€™s [2] approach where they modeled awareness syntactically by introducing a new modal operator for it. Halpern and RÃªgo [11] extended Fagin and Halpernâ€™s logic of awareness to deal with knowledge of unawareness. All of these papers focused on logic, and did not analyze the impact of unawareness in a strategic setting.

Feinbergâ€™s [?, ?] work is most similar work to ours. We discussed the high-level difference between our work and that of Feinberg in the introduction. Here we focus on some of the more detailed differences:

  • â€¢

    Feinberg does not model games semantically. He encodes all the information in the â„±â„±{\cal F} function syntactically, by describing each playerâ€™s awareness level and iterated nested awareness levels (e.g., what player 111 is aware that player 222 is aware that player 333 is aware of).

  • â€¢

    In dealing with extensive games, FeinbergÂ [?] assumes that the runs that a player is aware of completely determine what game he believes he is playing. It cannot be the case that there are two distinct â€œidentitiesâ€ of a player that have the same awareness level. As we discussed in SectionÂ 2, this assumption limits the applicability of the model.

  • â€¢

    Feinberg assumes that if player iğ‘–i is aware of player jğ‘—j, then iğ‘–i must be aware of some move of player jğ‘—j. We do not require such a condition since the analogous condition is not typically assumed in standard extensive games. For example, in a standard extensive game, a player may get a payoff even though there is no node where he can move. But it is trivial to add this requirement (as it would be trivial to drop in Feinbergâ€™s framework), and making it has no impact on the results.

  • â€¢

    FeinbergÂ [?] defines payoffs for player iğ‘–i by using what he calls â€œdefault actionsâ€ for players that iğ‘–i is unaware of. He says that this default action will be context dependent. We do not have such default actions in our setting; the payoff of a player in our framework is independent of the payoff of the players he is unaware of. The assumption of a default action seems somewhat problematic to us; it is not clear what the default move should be in general. Moreover, if two different players are unaware of player jğ‘—j, it is not clear why (or whether) they should assume the same default action.

  • â€¢

    In dealing with extensive games, FeinbergÂ [?] defines moves of nature by conditioning on the set of moves of nature the player is aware of. In our framework, this would amount to the following requirement:

    1. C13

      If Î“+âˆˆğ’¢superscriptÎ“ğ’¢\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}, hâˆˆH+â„superscriptğ»h\in H^{+}, P+â€‹(h)=isuperscriptğ‘ƒâ„ğ‘–P^{+}(h)=i, Ai+â€‹(h)=asuperscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–â„ğ‘{A}_{i}^{+}(h)=a, â„±â€‹(Î“+,h)=(Î“h,I)â„±superscriptÎ“â„superscriptÎ“â„ğ¼{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{h},I), hâ€²âˆˆHhsuperscriptâ„â€²superscriptğ»â„h^{\prime}\in H^{h}, Phâ€‹(hâ€²)=csuperscriptğ‘ƒâ„superscriptâ„â€²ğ‘P^{h}(h^{\prime})=c, and Mhâ€²hâˆ©MhÂ¯â€²â‰ âˆ…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â„superscriptâ„â€²subscriptğ‘€superscriptÂ¯â„â€²M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}\cap M_{\overline{h}^{\prime}}\neq\emptyset, then fchâ€‹(mâˆ£hâ€²)=fcâ€‹(mâˆ£hÂ¯â€²)fcâ€‹(Mhâ€²hâˆ£hÂ¯â€²)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â„ğ‘conditionalğ‘šsuperscriptâ„â€²subscriptğ‘“ğ‘conditionalğ‘šsuperscriptÂ¯â„â€²subscriptğ‘“ğ‘conditionalsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â„superscriptâ„â€²superscriptÂ¯â„â€²\mbox{$f^{h}_{c}(m\mid h^{\prime})$}=\frac{f_{c}(m\mid\overline{h}^{\prime})}{f_{c}(M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}\mid\overline{h}^{\prime})} for every mâˆˆMhâ€²hğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â„superscriptâ„â€²m\in M^{h}_{h^{\prime}} and fchâ€‹(mâˆ£hâ€²)=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â„ğ‘conditionalğ‘šsuperscriptâ„â€²0f^{h}_{c}(m\mid h^{\prime})=0 if mâˆ‰Mhâ€²hğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â„superscriptâ„â€²m\notin M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}.

    As Feinberg did, for that condition to be well defined we require that fcâ€‹(mâˆ£hÂ¯)â‰ 0subscriptğ‘“ğ‘conditionalğ‘šÂ¯â„0f_{c}(m\mid\overline{h})\neq 0 for all mâˆˆMhÂ¯ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘€Â¯â„m\in M_{\overline{h}} and histories hâ„h. As we discussed in SectionÂ 2, while we believe such a requirement makes sense if natureâ€™s move is interpreted objectively, it does not make sense in general so we do not assume this in every augmented game.

SadzikÂ [?] considers a logic of awareness, knowledge, and probability based on that of Heifetz, Meier, and Schipper [?], and uses it to give a definition of Bayesian equilibrium in normal-form games with awareness. Heifetz, Meier and SchipperÂ [?] also consider a generalized state-space model with interactive unawareness and probabilistic beliefs and give a definition of Bayesian equilibrium in normal-form games, without assuming Feinbergâ€™s restriction. Li [?] has also provided a model of unawareness in extensive games, based on her earlier work on modeling unawareness [18, 19]. Although her representation of a game with unawareness is quite similar to ours, her notion of generalized Nash equilibrium is different from ours. Just as we do, she requires that every player iğ‘–i make a best response with respect to his beliefs regarding other playerâ€™s strategies in the game Î“isuperscriptÎ“ğ‘–\Gamma^{i} that iğ‘–i considers possible. However, unlike us, she requires that these beliefs satisfy a consistency requirement that implies, for example, that if a player iğ‘–i is aware of the same set of moves for him at both information set I1subscriptğ¼1I_{1} in game Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} and information set I2subscriptğ¼2I_{2} in Î“2subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{2}, and these information sets correspond to the same information set in the underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma, then the local strategies Ïƒi,Î“1subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptÎ“1\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{1}} and Ïƒi,Î“2subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptÎ“2\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{2}} must agree at these information sets; that is, Ïƒi,Î“1â€‹(I1)=Ïƒi,Î“2â€‹(I2)subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptÎ“1subscriptğ¼1subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptÎ“2subscriptğ¼2\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{1}}(I_{1})=\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{2}}(I_{2}).

Ozbay [?] proposes a model for games with uncertainty where players may have different awareness levels regarding a move of nature. He assumes that one of the players is fully aware, and can tell the other player about these moves before the second player moves. Although our model can easily capture this setting, what is interesting about Ozbayâ€™s approach is that the second playerâ€™s beliefs about the probability of these revealed moves of are formed as part of the equilibrium definition. Filiz [?] uses Ozbayâ€™s model in the context of incomplete contracts in the presence of unforseen contingencies. In this setting, the insurer is assumed to be fully aware of the contingencies, and to decide strategically which contingencies to include in a contract, while the insuree may not be aware of all possible contingencies.

Finally, we remark that our notion of a game with awareness as consisting of the modelerâ€™s game together with description of which game each agent thinks is the actual game at each history has much in common with the intuition behind Gal and Pfefferâ€™s [?] notion of a Network of Influence Diagrams (NID). Formally, NIDs are a graphical language for representing uncertainty over decision-making models. A node in a NID (called a block by Gal and Pfeffer) represents an agentâ€™s subjective belief about the underlying game and what the strategies used by agents depend on. Each node (game) in a NID is associated with a multiagent influence diagram [15] (MAID), which is a compact representation of a game. A NID has directed edges between nodes labeled by pairs of the form (i,H)ğ‘–ğ»(i,H), where iğ‘–i is an agent and (in our language) Hğ»H is a set of histories. Intuitively, if there an edges from a node (game) Î“Î“\Gamma to a node Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} in a NID labeled by a pair (i,H)ğ‘–ğ»(i,H), then Hğ»H is a set a set of histories in Î“Î“\Gamma, there is an agent jğ‘—j that moves at all the histories in Hğ»H, and in game Î“Î“\Gamma, iğ‘–i believes that jğ‘—j believes that Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} is the true game when moving at a history hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in H.

Although Gal and Pfeffer do not try to handle notions of awareness with NIDs, it seems possible to extend them to handle awareness. To do this appropriately, consistency requirements similar to C1â€“C10 will need to be imposed.

7 Conclusion

We have generalized the representation of games to take into account agents who may not be aware of all the moves or all the other agents, but may be aware of their lack of awareness. Moreover, our representation is also flexible enough to deal with subjective games when there is lack of common knowledge about the game, even if awareness is not an issue. We have also shown how to define strategies and Nash equilibrium in such settings. These generalizations greatly increase the applicability of game-theoretic notions in multiagent systems. In large games involving many agents, agents will almost certainly not be aware of all agents and may well not be aware of all the moves that agents can make. Moreover, as we suggested in the introduction, even in well-understood games like chess, by giving awareness a more computational interpretation, we can provide a more realistic model of the game from the agentsâ€™ perspective. We remark that although we focus on generalizing extensive-form games, our framework is able to deal with normal-form games as well, since we can view normal-form games as a special case of extensive-form games.

There is clearly much more to be done to understand the role of awareness (and lack of awareness) in multiagent systems. We list some of the many issues here:

  • â€¢

    We have assumed perfect recall here. But in long games, it seems more reasonable to assume that agents do not have perfect recall. In a long chess game, typical players certainly do not remember all the moves that have been played and the order in which they were played. It is well known that even in single-agent games, considering agents with imperfect recall leads to a number of subtleties (c.f.Â [7, 24]). We suspect that yet more subtleties will arise when combining imperfect recall with lack of awareness.

  • â€¢

    In a Nash equilibrium of an extensive-form game, it may be the case that the move made at an information set is not necessarily a best response if that information set is not reached. For example, in the game described in FigureÂ 1, even if both players have common knowledge of the game, the profile where Ağ´A moves down and BğµB moves across is a Nash equilibrium. Nevertheless moving down is not a best response for BğµB if BğµB is actually called upon to play. The only reason that this is a Nash equilibrium is that BğµB does not in fact play. Sequential equilibrium [16] is a solution concept that is arguably more appropriate for an extensive-form game; it refines Nash equilibrium (in the sense that every sequential equilibrium is a Nash equilibrium) and does not allow solutions such as (downA, acrossB). Our representation of games with awareness (of unawareness) allows for relatively straightforward generalizations of such refinements of Nash equilibrium. However, there are subtleties involved in showing that generalized versions of these refinements always exist. For example, we no longer have a one-to-one correspondence between the generalized sequential equilibria of the game Î“âˆ—superscriptÎ“\Gamma^{*} and the sequential equilibria of the corresponding standard game Î“Î½superscriptÎ“ğœˆ\Gamma^{\nu}. Nevertheless, we believe that we should be able to use a more refined construction to show that a generalized sequential equilibrium exists in every game with awareness.

  • â€¢

    We have analyzed situations where agents may be unaware of some moves in the underlying game, may be aware of their unawareness, and may have completely false beliefs about the underlying game. Of course, there are other cases of interest where additional properties may hold. For example, consider a large geographically-dispersed game where agents interact only with nearby neighbors. In such a game, an agent may be unaware of exactly who is playing the game (although she may realize that there are other agents besides her neighbors, and even realize that the moves made by distant agents may have an indirect effect on her). To model such a situation, we may want to have virtual moves after which the game does not end, and to allow agents to be aware of subsequences of histories in the underlying game. We suspect that a straightforward extension of the ideas in this paper can deal with such situations, but we have not worked out the details.

  • â€¢

    There has been a great deal of work on computing Nash equilibria. As we have shown, a generalized Nash equilibrium of a game with awareness is a Nash equilibrium of a standard game. However, this standard game can be rather large. Are there efficient computational techniques for computing generalized Nash equilibrium in interesting special cases?

  • â€¢

    If there is little shared knowledge regarding the underlying game, the set ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} of augmented games can be quite large, or even infinite. Is it important to consider all the iterated levels of unawareness encoded in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G}? Halpern and Moses [?] showed that, in analyzing coordinated attack, no finite level of knowledge suffices; common knowledge is needed for coordination. Stopping at any finite level has major implications. Rubinstein [?] considered a variant of the coordinated attack problem with probabilities, and again showed that no finite level suffices (and significant qualitative differences arise if only a finite part of hierarchy of knowledge is considered). On the other hand, Weinstein and Yildiz [?] provide a condition under which the effect of playersâ€™ kğ‘˜kth order beliefs is exponentially decreasing in kğ‘˜k. While we strongly suspect that there are games in which higher-order unawareness will be quite relevant, just as with the Weinstein-Yildiz result, there may be conditions under which higher-order awareness becomes less important, and a simpler representation may suffice. Moreover, it may be possible to use NIDs to provide a more compact representation of games of awareness in many cases of interest (just as Bayesian networks provide a compact representation of probability distributions in many cases of interest), leading to more efficient techniques for computing generalized Nash equilibrium.

We hope to explore some of these issues in forthcoming work.

Corollary 3.1: Every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium.

Proof: For games with perfect recall, there is a natural isomorphism between mixed strategies and behavioral strategies, so a Nash equilibrium in behavior strategies can be viewed as a Nash equilibrium in mixed strategies [22]. Moreover, mixed-strategy Nash equilibria of an extensive-form game are the same as the mixed-strategy Nash equilibria of its normal-form representation. Salonen [?] showed that there exists a Nash equilibrium in mixed strategies in a normal form games with an arbitrary set Nğ‘N of players if, for each player iğ‘–i, the set Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} of pure strategies of player iğ‘–i is a compact metric space, and the utility functions ui:Sâ†’Iâ€‹R:subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–â†’ğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘…u_{i}:S\rightarrow\mbox{$I\!\!R$} are continuous for all iâˆˆNğ‘–ğ‘i\in N, where Iâ€‹Rğ¼ğ‘…I\!\!R is the set of real numbers and S=Î iâˆˆNâ€‹Siğ‘†subscriptÎ ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S=\Pi_{i\in N}S_{i}, the set of pure strategies, is endowed with the product topology. Since in Î“Î½superscriptÎ“ğœˆ\Gamma^{\nu}, every player has a finite number of pure strategies, Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} is clearly a compact metric space. Moreover, since each playerâ€™s utility depends only on the strategies of a finite number of other players, it is easy to see that ui:Sâ†’Iâ€‹R:subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–â†’ğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘…u_{i}:S\rightarrow\mbox{$I\!\!R$} is continuous for each player iâˆˆNğ‘–ğ‘i\in N. It follows that there exists a Nash equilibrium of Î“Î½superscriptÎ“ğœˆ\Gamma^{\nu}. Thus, the corollary is immediate from TheoremÂ 3.1. Â
